Issues.Title: Make wording in the directives more inclusive
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ feature request

### Description
I led a workshop on web development for the youth. A girl asked me a question what a certain line on an angular template meant. She was unusually shy and had trouble pointing at the line. Later she said in private that she didn't know how to read ng-repeat out loud. Spelling it reminded her of an ugly racial slur. I understand that it is just an unfortunate abbreviation, but it limits the pool of the talented folks who could learn angular.

### Describe the solution you'd like
Replacing the ng with ang or something similar would be awesome. It will make the project more inclusive. It also matches the library name better, so it's easier to remember. There is evidence that it is a confusing name https://stackoverflow.com/questions/14669322/what-does-the-ng-stand-for-in-angular-js-directives

### Describe alternatives you've considered
This is a big change. We could start it by improving documentation and accepting two prefixes by default.

Issues.Title: fix(ivy): properly compile NgModules with forward referenced types
Issues.Body:
Previously, ngtsc would resolve forward references while evaluating the
bootstrap, declaration, imports, and exports fields of NgModule types.
However, when generating the resulting ngModuleDef, the forward nature of
these references was not taken into consideration, and so the generated JS
code would incorrectly reference types not yet declared.

This commit fixes this issue by introducing function closures in the
NgModuleDef type, similarly to how NgComponentDef uses them for forward
declarations of its directives and pipes arrays. ngtsc will then generate
closures when required, and the runtime will unwrap them if present.

Issues.Title: HostBinding('class') syntax to honor hosts's existing classes
Issues.Body:
## Feature request

### Description

When using the following code (assume it is code for 'my-component'):

```ts
@HostBinding('class') 
@Input() type: string;
```

there should be an option to **append** the class to existing class list rather than **replace** all existing classes. The `HostBindingDecorator` could honor all other existing classes that might have been set in the template for other purposes.

This way `@HostBinding` would allow for what this syntax `[ngClass]="[class1, class2]"` allows - ie. appending classes of unknown names.

### Current and desired behavior

Given the above component input, and this markup:

`<my-component class="something" type="type1"></my-component>`

the template will be rendered as follows:

`<my-component class="type1"></my-component>`

while the desired result is:

`<my-component class="something type1"></my-component>`

### Workaround

I am not saying that there is no workaround for the above, but it requires injecting `Renderer` and `ElementRef` along with the code to handle the classes. Also, given that for some reason `Renderer` does not have a handy method `toggleClass(classname, condition)`, that code becomes even more verbose.

### Suggested syntax

In order to assure backwards compatibility (for users who have already used the current behavior to purposely override all existing classes), `HostBindingDecorator` could accept a config parameter, something like: `@HostBinding('class', {append: true})` to explicitly specify new behavior with `true`.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "HostBinding('class') syntax to honor hosts's existing classes" (#29188)

### Description

Schematics runner can accept a JavsScript file as a `factory` of a schematic. 
To create boilerplates in my app, it seems a good solution to create local schematics. But it is not easy to get ready.

Issues.Title: fix(@ngtools/webpack): `getCurrentDirectory` should not return a devkit path
Issues.Body:
At the moment we are leaking devkit paths as `getCurrentDirectory` is used by the ngtsc compiler if no `rootDir` directories is provided.

`getCurrentDirectory` is also used to construct the `rootDirs` option which is causing this to be incorrect as under Windows as `rootDirs` will be have an invalid value example: `/c/foo/bar`

This PR complements https://github.com/angular/angular/pull/29151

**Note** that this currently works because we are normalizing paths with posix seperators and is mimicking the behaviour of the logical file system used by the ngtsc.

Issues.Title: fix(schematics): do not run migrations multiple times
Issues.Body:
Currently when someone runs the update schematic within a CLI project,
the migration could be executed multiple times for the same `tsconfig` path
This can happen because the `getProjectTsConfigPaths` function _can_
incorrectly return the same tsconfig multiple times. The paths are not properly
deduped as we don't normalize the determined project tsconfig paths.

e.g. `/tsconfig.json` exists and the common tsconfig path is detected. At the same time the
workspace configuration specifies `tsconfig.json` in the project options. Both paths refer
to the same tsconfig project, but are different strings and therefore aren't filtered out
by the `Set` which contains all possible tsconfig locations --> migrations are executed
for both paths.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(schematics): do not run migrations multiple times" (#15424)

Issues.Title: distinguising MatRadioGroup change event from DOM change event
Issues.Body:
#### Please describe the feature you would like to request.

MatRadioGroup raises event with a name different from change

#### What is the use-case or motivation for this proposal?

Currently, the only output of MatRadioGroup is (change).
It has the same name as the native DOM event.
If you wrap a <mat-radio-group> outside for example an <input>, then the change event raised by the <input> element will bubble up MadRadioGroup. The handler will be confused, receiving a DOM event without event.source or event.value.

Yes, the handler should check the event object first, but it is a trap for every programmer.

use case: I use a radio group so that user will be filling different part of the form according to the radio button choice. something like only fill in part A when you choose option A, and B B. So I got all sorts of controls inside the radio group.

If MatRadioGroup has used something like sectionChange of MatSelect, then this ambiguity won't happen.

Issues.Title: improve support for readonly controls OR improve how to subscribe to form changes with disabled controls
Issues.Body:
#### Please describe the feature you would like to request.
Suggest there be a clean way to either a) get data from disabled controls or alternately b) improve support for readonly controls. Solution is requested in terms of best practices and/or feature enhancements.

#### What is the use-case or motivation for this proposal?
When using a custom component with a form, the form changes need to be watched and emitted to the parent. If the form has values that ought to be readonly, til now I've used the disabled flag *as a workaround* because a) readonly fields have poor visual appearance -- they are not greyed out b) formbuilder supports initializing as disabled, but not initializing as readonly (as shown here https://angular.io/api/forms/FormBuilder#control).

However, when using the workaround, it becomes difficult to watch and emit changes "cleanly" for disabled fields e.g. subscribing to form.valueChanges doesn't get disabled fields, necessitating a duplicative call to getRawValue() after subscribing to changes, to get all the form field data.

#### Is there anything else we should know?
Potential solutions:
a) advise if using readonly attribute is the best practice, rather than using 'disabled' to prevent data entry. If so, hoping there can be some improvements on styling of readonly controls (e.g. they should be greyed out), and also formbuilder should be able to initialize them as readonly. 

b) if angular doesn't intend to support readonly atribute, and instead rely on 'disabled' attribute, then ideally there would be something similar to form.valueChanges that actually gets all form values including disabled controls. 

If (b) is the solution path, then it's low priority admittedly, since it just avoids a little code duplication. I think the core question though is whether there ought to be better support for readonly controls, and if the angular framework intends to maintain a distinction between 'disabled' vs. 'readonly'. 

For my purposes, I mainly disable controls in order to achieve the readonly effect, and then I make a point to getRawValue data so i get all the data. From my research on stackoverflow etc. it appears others do similar workarounds.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "improve support for readonly controls OR improve how to subscribe to form changes with disabled controls" (#15399)
